abstract.text: An
object is a vertical matrix of
objects to implement the fields.

inlineContent.text: Use NSTextField directly instead, and consider NSStackView for layout assistance

platforms.message: Use NSTextField directly instead, and consider NSStackView for layout assistance
platforms.name: macOS

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
A set of methods that defines a way to add animation to an existing class with a minimum of API impact.
A set of methods for getting and setting the appearance attributes of a view.
An object that stores image data in a form that can be readily transferred to the screen.
A set of methods that the destination object (or recipient) of a dragged image must implement.
A user interface element that contains and displays text, scroll, and browser views, in addition to other view subclasses.
An
object is a vertical matrix of
objects to implement the fields.
Adds a new entry to the end of the receiver and gives it the specified title.
Returns the entry at the specified index.
Displays the entry at the specified index.
Returns the index of the entry whose tag is
Returns the index of the selected entry.
Inserts an entry with the specified title into the receiver.
The preferred width of the form’s cells when using Auto Layout.
Removes and releases the entry at the specified index.
Selects the entry at the specified index.
Sets whether the receiver’s entries should display a bezel around their editable text.
Sets whether the receiver’s entries should display a border around their editable text fields.
Sets the width of all the entries in the receiver.
Sets the size of the receiver’s frame size to the specified value.
Sets the spacing between entries
Sets the preferred text field width used by Auto Layout.
Sets the alignment for all of the receiver’s editable text.
Sets the writing direction for the text content of every control embedded in the form.
Sets the font for all of the receiver’s editable text fields
Sets the alignment for all of the entry titles.
Sets the writing direction for the title of every control embedded in the form.
Sets the font for all of the entry titles.
The
class is used to implement text entry fields in a form. The left part of an
object contains a title. The right part contains an editable text entry field.
A legacy interface for grouping radio buttons or other types of cells together.
An object that handles the measurement and display of a single menu item in its encompassing frame.
An object that represents an OpenGL graphics context, into which all OpenGL calls are rendered.
A subclass of
that is suitable for rendering OpenGL into layers.
An object that provides access to accelerated offscreen rendering.
An object that specifies the types of buffers and other attributes of the OpenGL context.
A view that displays OpenGL content in a view.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
A protocol that a custom class can adopt to manage the enabled state of a UI element.
A set of methods for dynamically associating a tool tip with a view.
A layer that provides a layer suitable for rendering OpenGL content.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
